description.text:
This is an EggBot engraved glass Christsmas ball using Inkscape graphic program.
The art is a piece of public domain Clip Art from Open Clip Art Library created by artist "Johnny_automatic".
This is my 1st item using the EggBot engraver option.

Create an Inkscape drawing file and print to the EggBot through the EggBot extension.
The drawing can also be drawn with colored "Sharpie" pens rather than engraving.

comments.text: I no longer use my Eggbot, but as I recall it took about 30 minutes, the ball was about 3" in diameter.  The problem with doing the Christmas balls is that they are very fragile and the success rate was very poor as the engraver tip would engrave too deeply.  If you can find balls that are a little heavier than normal you may have more success.

description.text:
Problem - I use a quad lock to mount my phone to my stem. I have an iPhone 6s+ which when mounted takes up all of the room on the stem and handlebars. I cannot mount my headlight or anything else to my handlebars.

Solution - I have created this bike mount as an extension to the handle bar. It provides enough room for my hands to rest comfortably and reach the brakes. It allows for my phone to be mounted out in front of me like a dashboard. It also provides enough extra room on the cross bar to mount additional items.

My bike's handlebars are 31.8mm. I have created this to fit a 31.8mm handlebar. Feel free to adjust for your own needs.

For Print Settings:

Mount Arm x 2: ABS - Infill: 70%, Shell Thickness 1mm, Layer Height: .22, Supports: Yes
Mount Stem: ABS - Infill 35%, Shell Thickness 2mm, Layer Height: .22, Supports: Yes
Mount Crossbar: ABS - Infill 35%, Shell Thickness 2mm, Layer Height: .22 Supports: No
Mount Arm Grip x 2: NinjaFlex (Lulzbot Cura NinjaFlex defaults)
Mount Arm Strap X 5: NinjaFlex (Lulzbot Cura NinjaFlex defaults)
Mount Stem Grip: NinjaFlex (Lulzbot Cura NinjaFlex defaults)

Mount Arm Grip
  1. Cut the Mount Arm Grip to fit.
  2. Glue the Mount Arm Grip to the Mount Arm
Mount Stem Grip
  1. Cut the Mount Stem Grip to fit.
  2. Glue the Mount Stem Grip to the Mount Stem.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Requested by SkyKing...

The Grumman American AA-1 series is a family of light, two-seat aircraft. The family includes the original American Aviation AA-1 Yankee Clipper and AA-1A Trainer, the Grumman American AA-1B Trainer and TR-2. This particular model is mostly based on the AA-1 Yankee Clipper. Documentation on this aircraft was sparse due to it's status as an older trainer. The AA-1 was originally designed as a kit-build under FAR 23. When no kits were sold, it was re-designed as a trainer, and a very forgiving trainer indeed. The design of the entire airframe was simple by design philosophy, with the wings interchangeable on either side. I attempted to "cut" into the fuselage mesh to have the wing pegs connecting inboard as opposed to outboard, but it was only with limited success. Enjoy!

Version 1.0.2

comments.text: Thank you so much for recreating N9293L.  I flew her for nearly 10 years and as a trainer, I have to say, she was very demanding.  In stalls, she liked to drop a wing and of course, spins were prohibited (they were unrecoverable after one revolution).  But for construction, Jim Bede's design was simple, effective and just sleek.  My Flying Pumpkin will live again!

The Beechcraft 1900 is a 19-passenger, pressurized twin-engine turboprop fixed-wing aircraft that was manufactured by Beechcraft. It was designed, and is primarily used, as a regional airliner. It is also used as a freight aircraft and corporate transport.

Sadly the turboprop as a mainstream regional carrier has died away in the US. Still popular in the rest of the world, turboprops for some reason obtained a negative stigma in the eyes of the American public, who were more in favor of seemingly more reliable jets. I first saw this aircraft in a flight simulator I downloaded when I was little. I know little else about it's history, only that it was fun to model!

As always, if you see anything right, wrong, or an idea to improve, let me know!

Version 1.0.2 - It was brought to my attention the errors near the wing roots, and an issue a few people have had with the nose. These have been corrected. Any other trouble let me know!!

description.text:
The viewing panes are 156mm x 104mm x 2mm. The thinnest sections allow light to pass through, especially if you use translucent filament (I choose glow in the dark). Any image can be set-up on the panes, but this lamp was designed to use standard photo lithophanes. The base was designed around a cheap LED tap light I found on Amazon.

The lithophane frame sections are 4 prints of the same piece. A dual tongue and groove fits the parts together and helps hold in the images during assembly. My printed base is my original base, so the light is too close to the panes. I raised the height of the walls on the base to sink the light lower below the panes to improve visibility.

I used the following site and settings for creating the lithophanes in my test print.

http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/

title: Z-switch setting screw to adjust the 0 point of the z-axis of the heatbed (for K8200 and 3Drag)

description.text:
For easy adjust the higt of the z-end-switch.
so i can set the high by diverent coutings af the mirror (blangk/kapton/bluetape)
you need the 3 printet parts
1x M3x20 (or loger)
2x M4x50mm
1x M5x80mm
4x M5 nut
1x M5 security nut
1x Spring 9x35mm it is possibe thad you must sand the 1mm horizontal markers in the bottom part, There are different markers at the top-part.
2x smal markers
1x marker with a dot on top
and 5 markers (they grow up) at the marker with the dot you must adjust with the screw 0,25mm distance betwen nozzle and heatbed (and fix it with ne conter nut at the top)
so you had an offset from -0.2mm to +0,5mm
To see the markers bether you can paint it with nail color or an edding.

comments.text: Brilliant idea, thanks a lot.  Maybe you can tweak the design a bit to work better with the popular Z motor mount? Doing so would allow you to make the entire assembly a bit thicker and more sturdy (as the microswitch would be positioned to the outside).

title: FDL-1 Blaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
FDL-1 Blaster

The FDL-1 is a robotic foam dart launcher. It is high powered, fully automatic, web enabled, and can be converted into multiple forms, this being the handheld blaster version. It shoots Nerf Mega size darts and has a capacity of 12. It has ranges over 100' shooting parallel to the ground and I've seen it hit 120fps on a chronograph. It's intense and awesome.

Please visit FDL1.com for more info. I have a web shop there selling assembled blasters, kits, and electronics bundles to pair with your printed shell.


Watch the FDL-1 in action

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.254

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Designed to fit no smaller than a 6x6x6" bed and with a 0.4mm nozzle in mind. You shouldn't need supports but a brim around some of the long skinny parts helps.

I always use a heated bed and have only ever printed the FDL-1 in PLA. I find it prints more accurately than ABS and is for the most part just as strong. Plus it's easier on my printers. There's no reason not to try ABS or any other filament though, I'd be curious to know how it goes.

You may have to do some light sanding and you'll need a 6-32 and a 10-32 tap to thread a number of holes. I really made a point while designing the FDL-1 to try to make it as print and play as possible but everyone's printer is a little different so a little adjustment may be necessary.

I have setup a repository on GitHub to house the code for the Photon, electronic schematics, and other files. You can find that here:


FDL-1 Blaster GitHub Repo

comments.text: Have you considered making a mag-fed version of this? Just a question.
comments.author: NickVanderplop

comments.text: Yes...and no. I originally pondered making the FDL-1 mag-fed but it's a pain to find Mega mags so I went with a revolver. While I think it would be cool to have a mag-fed FDL-1 it would really be an entirely different blaster. I used it as an engineering exercise to see how usable I could make a revolver with the aid of some electronics. Mag-fed blasters are all about rate of fire and quick changes. The FDL-1 is more of a constant load and conserve ammo kind of blaster. It's a completely different play style. I'd like to make a belt fed version happen at some point and maybe removable clips but like I said, being mag-fed would be a whole different ball game likely warranting a major redesign. I would probably design a mag-fed elite dart blaster before turning the FDL-1 into one.
comments.author: NickVanderplop

comments.text:
I get what you're saying. I used an overhauled Barricade for almost an entire war, and it is VERY different from my normal Stryfe.
But that's beside the point, because I wasn't saying SWAPPABLE mags, I was saying have 1 fixed mag that you can continuously load darts into, like the Magnus, but having a capacity to speak of. That would solve the problem (at least I see it as a problem) of only being able to load 1 barrel at a time. And make it less mechanically complex. But that's spoiling the fun a little, isn't it? You'd have to make a mechanical burst fire or something to make up for it.
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Oh, I gotcha. That's a cool idea. Then you could load a few at once and top off as needed. It might be interesting even to make the revolver into a built in drum of sorts.
comments.author: NickVanderplop

comments.text:
Yeah! or a double-stack mag! If you do make a drum, MAKE IT SYMMETRICAL. PLEASE.
but either way, the mag solves the problem of empty chambers, because a dart will always be at the top, unless you're completely out. I think the hard part would be getting a system that retains the darts, yet still allows you to add more, without squishing them.
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: What material would you suggest to print the FDL-1?
comments.author: Warcorer

comments.text: I printed it out of ABS. I didn't need to make any special accomodations in order to make it work. The shrinkage rate didn't matter. I have a heated chamber though, so the large parts were easily controlled
comments.author: Warcorer

comments.text: I personally prefer PLA. Some of the tolerances are pretty tight between some of the moving parts and PLA tends to warp less throughout prints making it more accurate. I've never actually printed an entire blaster in ABS though. My Printrbots don't heat up enough without enclosures so until I build a couple I honestly can't say one way or another. I have had one person successfully use ABS though and it fires so it's certainly possible. I've recently been made aware of a heat resistant PLA by MatterGeeks that I want to try. I take the white blaster in the pictures out to Nerf wars all the time and it's been fine in the hot sun but that heat resistance would be cool.
comments.author: Warcorer

comments.text: Posting the Github link as it was only in the previous "prototype" version https://github.com/jkovarovics
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Thanks! I'm working on getting a BOM and more complete wiring diagrams up there.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text:
A suggestion.
tilt your shooter motors at least a few degrees. Left one one way, right one the other. This will put some spin on the dart as it shoots forward and should make it fly straighter (as long as the darts are not too warped). It might also allow for the use of different types of darts.

Yep, this is called canted flywheels in the Nerf community. I'd like to give it a try at some point. It wouldn't be too hard to tweak the model a bit to try it out. I've had discussions with people about the effectiveness of it on Nerf darts and opinions vary. There is a high end aluminum flywheel cage out of Germany that is popular among the more hardcore Nerfers that uses about 6 degrees of cant. It seems to work well but we're talking about a precision machined part. It may work well just because of that. I'd be curious to give it a try and do some objective testing. Good suggestion, thanks.

An American called Hawki007 is also making a custom cage. THe product he ships is cast resin, but his test cages were 3d printed, and they got the same results. However, this may be because of the 19/32 inch brass barrel guiding the darts in his and the German cage. Once I get my printer working (it's a homemade from 2011 that I rebuilt, somewhat poorly) I'll make test cages that are exactly alike except for the cant to see whether it has any effect (and what the optimal cant is)
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Cool, I didn't realize he made cages too. I met him at DartCon and I knew he casted parts for Stryfes but not cages. I guess I should have paid more attention. Let me know how it goes. One of these days I'll get around to sciencing the heck out of some of this stuff, but for now I may have to defer it to the community. As it stands, the FDL-1 is surprisingly accurate, especially for a Mega blaster, and I'm pretty happy with that.
comments.author: NickVanderplop

comments.text: Yup, he makes cages. I should be getting one for myself in the mail in a couple of weeks.  I too would much like to get on with sciencing, but as I said, my 3d printer is being a punk and refusing to work.
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

title: The Lamest 3D Printed Thing Ever (Ofuda Container)

description.text:
As the title suggests, this is 3D-printed Ofuda container. An Ofuda is a Japanese term for a small piece of paper/cloth with a writing on it. I shamelessly stole this idea from the anime Sailor Moon, where Sailor Mars uses a similar Ofuda to defeat her evil enemies like a boss!

When one says whatever is written on the paper, the ofuda execution is complete (whatever that means lol). My Ofuda says "aku-ryo tai-san!", which translates from Japanese to English roughly as "evil spirits, be gone!".

https://youtu.be/x1Fls9aMN60

Messed up and missed the tank body with the holes. It is up there now. I have also added one that is hollow. It has 3mm walls and printed a bit faster with my printrbot.

Added a new turret - newturrett3a. It is a much smoother creation. Both work though, take your pick.

The PB could not handle the top though, so if I were to print it again I would add some supports. My favorite frugal trick is just to add a few 2mm cylinders and then bust them off after printing. The hollow version has a hole at the bottom for easy busting, or you could use it as a trojan tank... err horse. =)

Love the tank by Shimongraff, but wanted to print the axles separate from the tank. Not a fan of supports and if 1 fails the entire project is toast. I added sockets for the axles so they can be printed as needed.

The tracks are not as tight as I would like, but I am letting them be for now.

My other tweak was that I wanted a turret that could elevate. I played with the connectors in TinkerCD to create one. It is not the most efficient design, but I had a ton of fun working through the process,

Lots of room for improvement, so have at it if you are interested. Importing stl files into TinkerCAD is amazingly simple.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BHQxMGwDw3T/?taken-by=hlmodtech

title: Filastruder Electronics Enclosure v3 & Hopper Funnel v3 (Based on the original by Tim Elmore)

description.text:
I added "Filastruder", "MAIN", "MOTOR" script to the front panel, vents along the top, angled support for front panel.  As well as a screw down tab on the left side.  
This holds down the Sestos controller perfectly no need to fasten it to the Enclosure or the wooden support.  
Fits #8 screws on all holes (I used the same diameter screw holes as Tim's design).  I did remove the front right upper hole as I was not sure the purpose of it.  
The Hopper has a tapered bottom, instead of being flat.

Instructions are the same as Tim's:
  • Infill 40%
  • 3 Shells total - I don't remember seeing the # of shells mentioned
  • Full Support (Required mainly for the screw mount on the left side, but also gives nice even switch openings)**
    • ** Tim's did not need support. I printed it in ABS, but it would probably be better in PLA.

description.text:
Have an acrylic prusa i3 clone but upgraded to a proper aluminum bed? This mount should help replace the stock acrylic belt mount for the Y carriage (bed mount). This is also for the thin 2.5 belt, not the thicker belt found on some setups.
There are 2 files, one is a fixed non-adjustable mount, the other is a clamp style that needs a M3x12 and M3 nut. Both need two M3 screws (8-12 length should be fine) and nuts to mount to the carriage. On the clamp style, the nut fits really tight so may need pliers to force it in there.

title: Bulldog extruder assembly - X carriage + mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bulldog extruder assembly - e3d v6 + inductive sensor compatible.

This assembly is compatible with most printers that use a horizontal x axis.
Mendel, mendelmax, prusa mendel, airwolf 3d etc.

-- It is a very sturdy design, the weight is well devided.
-- E3d v6 is easily removable ( you can just pull it out of the assembly and put it back in)
-- The original e3d fan duct is compatible, you just have to turn it around (= no issue)
-- The inductive sensor is easy adjustable/ removable and close to the hot end
-- The extruder is no longer the limiting factor of your z height, your x ends are. I gained 3.5 cm compared to wades extruder.
-- Extruder is placed perfectly for filament loading.
-- It just looks good ^^

Bill of material:

1 Bulldog extruder lite or xl
1 e3d v6
1 M5 10mm
3x M5 15mm or longer
1x M3 20mm, smaller is probably ok.
4x lm8uu2
1x Optional inductive sensor.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendelmax 1.5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I would go for 100 procent infill , especially for the x carriage to make it robust.

There are some minor cosmetic errors in the model, dont worry every fits fine, and you won't see it in the final assembly.

description.text:
Got tired of the blind on the door at work swinging all over the place when opening and closing the door. The cheap factory retainers that hold the bottom of the blind stationary to the door had snapped off (thin cheap plastic) and I decided that I would make some new ones. They are a lot beefier than the originals and I designed the holding pin a little longer (can be trimmed to what your need is) to allow better holding of the blind. You're more than welcome to change this design to your liking but please give credit of original to me in your postings or remixes.

Designed and printed as a pair, one for each side of the lower part of the blind. I laid them on their backs so there is no need for rafts or support.
This is my first design so go easy on me. LOL Enjoy!

description.text:
Here is a link to my latest quadcopter design

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1753864

This is the first drone that I have designed and built. It is a 450 class drone meaning the diagonal measures 450 mm. It was designed for aerial photography with space for a gimbal and GoPro sized camera. It runs off of the APM 2.8 flight controller, 1000 Kv brushless motors, and has a flight time of 20 minutes when using a 5000 mAh battery. As this was my first time building a drone it was a huge learning curve for me but now I have learned a lot, so feel free to ask me any questions.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print with a heated bed or else the prints will warp up a lot.

The Parts

The parts you will need are as follow

A flight controller

  • I chose the APM 2.8 because of the low price, the user friendliness, and the easy mounting.

http://www.ebay.ca/itm/APM-2-8-ArduPilot-Flight-Controller-6M-GPS-433Mhz-Telemetry-Power-Module-se-/391273664548?hash=item5b19ba5024:g:86wAAOSwFnFWBV6C

A power system

  • I used a power module for the flight controller which simply connected to the battery and powered the flight controller without any other wiring. (included with the flight controller I bought)

  • To power the motors I used a power distribution board attached to the other side of the power module.

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__88926__Matek_Systems_Power_Distribution_5_in_1_LED_Lighting_Control_Low_Voltage_Alarm_LED_Power_Hub_V3.html

  • I used a 3 cell (11.1 V) 5200 mAh battery for 20 minutes of flight time

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__56839__Multistar_High_Capacity_3S_5200mAh_Multi_Rotor_Lipo_Pack.html

The motors

  • I chose 1000 kv motors (1000 rpm/volt) with 30 amp ESC (electronic speed controllers)

https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B00CTDLX98/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=A3GO9E4RCWDUQZ&psc=1

Assembly Parts

-The screws - all the wholes are designed to fit 2.6-3 mm screws

This is a picture of the wiring schematic I used.

title: X-Wing Pilot Leg Flares and Data Cylinders(tops)

description.text:
In addition to the Chest Box I designed, there were more parts that I made because paying for replicas of these parts just felt ridiculous. Included are the models for the Leg Flares seen on the boot and the Data Cylinders on the arm.

Data Cylinders: This model only included the top of the cylinder, but there is a hole at the bottom for a 3/8" dowell to fit in. The length of the dowell is up to you. There were BARELY any dimensions or sizes for this part, so i made it 2 9/8" (6.5 cm) tall and used reference photos to design it.

Leg Flares: 4" tall, 1 3/4" wide cylinders that are kind of round on each ends...not much and it might be easier just to buy wooden dowells of this size but that's up to you.

Leave Feedback, I hope this helps a lot of you trying to do the X-Wing Pilot costume like I am.

remixed_from.title: Creator Pro / Replicator / Duplicator X-Axis Carriage for E3D Cyclops/Chimera EXPERIMENTAL

title: Creator Pro / Replicator 2x / Duplicator X-Axis ADAPTER for E3D Cyclops/Chimera

description.text:
THIS HAS BEEN TESTED AND WORKS BEAUTIFULLY!!!

This design allows you to reuse your stock dual extruder carriage on your Replicator 2x clone (Creator Pro, Duplicator 4, ect) and mount the E3D Cyclops or Chimera extruder. I'm not the type to document as I go, but I dove headfirst into running the Cyclops on my Duplicator 4s today, and it works beautifully. The printer really benefits heavily from the reduced carriage weight.

You pretty much remove the stock extruder assembly from the carriage by the heat spreader then put this in it's place with some m3 screws and nuts. The adapter itself will fit on the carriage with the bulge going to the front or the back, but the extruder fan only fits facing the front and with the screws for that fan only in the top holes. It's a tight fit, but everything clears and has plenty of breathing room. The oblong hole is for wire routing.

IMPORTANT NOTE FOR CYCLOPS!
Sailfish firmware is crazy with toolhead offsets. If you enter a value that is -4mm to 4mm, it adds that value to the default of 33mm, anything over and it is an absolute value from tool 0's position. This means setting the offset to 0 (since both tools are the same nozzle) makes T1 print +33mm off. The only workaround I've found is with Simplify3d. Under the Gcode tab, you can set toolhead offsets. Set Tool 1 to -33.00 and click the check beside "Apply toolhead offsets to G-code." Make sure the toolhead offsets on the printer's menu are both set to 0. This will make everything come out perfect.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print it with the flat side down and use supports.

description.text: What can you do with a 3d printer, some sugru, and some shock cord? Hang a garland on a brick house, of course!

Print several clips, and paint them to match your house. Use some sugru to glue them on. Knot and loop some paracord through the hook and around the garland to hold it in place. More detail here: http://swampcastle.blogspot.com/2012/01/garland-attached-to-brick.html

It's again 'that' time of the year. The summer tires have to be changed for the winter ones. Until now I always marked my tires with chalk, only to spend hours of deciphering six month later wit a good portion of estimation and sheer guessing.
But no more! This time I made some tire markers that fit on the valves and say cleary FR, FL, RR, RL. If I still mix them up next spring, I got bigger problems than misreading my own marks.

title: LED Light Ring Mount  for Rostock Max Effector Platform - Fan Shroud Combo

description.text:
Honestly, I am very happy with this part. It's very simple and probably only 2.5 people in the world can even use it (fewer would bother.) If I were you, I would buy this printer and upgrade to carbon fiber arms, just to use this. I'm telling you it's REALLY nice. I'm sitting under it's glow right now.

The LED light ring I designed is made to attach to the Rostock Max Effector Platform/Fan Combo http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1167280. I think the light ring WILL interfere with the stock arms (but if you feel adventurous... give it a go.) There is no interference with the Trick Laser carbon fiber arms. Basically, this is of limited use, but it is awesome.

The LED light ring that this was designed for is the "Everbrightt 1-Pair White 80MM 63SMD COB LED Angel Eyes With SHELL Halo Ring Bulb Fog light Lamps For Car" http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B015Z7B470.

your going to need to remove the LED ring from the clear plastic diffusor, I tested it and the diffuser doesn't do much, except take up space, so thats gone. Although, if you are one of the 2.5 other people that could actually use this, the diffuser also has clips for mounting which could be helpful in designing a new version of this very mount.

I used a little hot glue to mount the LED ring into the mount.

The light flickers when you are printing directly to the power supply. to solve this I added a DROK® DC Step Down Variable Voltage Regulaor 36V to 24V 12V 5V 3.3V 3V Buck Converter Electronic Volt Stabilizer Car Automatic Battery Adjustable Regulated Power Supply DIY LM2596 Module Board. http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00VUHVX6W.
Now there is no more flicker.

Lastly, I didn't want this thing ALWAYS on when I'm printing, so... I added something like http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B012IJ3DZY. (although mine was different)

I mounted the toggle in a mirror image of the power switch near the Y tower. lets face it, asymmetry of the power switch bothers you a bit.

Good Luck!

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure your slicer supports the bottom well, but make sure it also does not put support inside the tube.  :-)

description.text:
This is a simple tube-type filament guide designed to clip onto the edge of my Prusa i3's frame, to direct the filament from a spool at the front, to the side and up the back to my extruder motor. There is no mounting hole on the part, rather I figured you'd just attach it with a drop or two of superglue.

This one is for the right side of the printer; the photo is of a mirrored/left-sided version generated by the slicer I use.

This will need some reasonably well-tuned cooling, as it has lots of overhangs (by way of round cross-sections). It needs to be printed with supports, preferably with the fork sticking up (either way would work, but that orientation will take less time to print).

The forks are spaced 5.8 mm apart, and the tube has a nominal inner diameter of about 4.3 mm.

author: rkarr

description.text:
I just fixed the model that RossRobotics so skillfully crafted.  Many of the parts were inverted which prevented it from slicing correctly, for me.   
I printed the model using 2 perimeters @ .3mm an .15 infill.  I had edited out some of the fine detail (tiny satellite dishes, etc) before printing, but they are present in this file.   
I used Wings 3d to take apart the model.  It is a very simple program.  Although it lacks some distinct features, it does allow a model to be broken up into its original parts, which allows you to edit things, like taking out small details or modifying just a single part or two of the whole thing without much effort.

comments.text: Thanks for posting this repaired model up.  I haven't had a chance to do any modeling in a while do to real life.

title: Jet powered model boat (inspired in NQD)

description.text:
I have seen a lot videos of people who bougth an NQD to upgrade the powerplant and have a nice and funny model boat, i wanted also but i couldnt find the model i was looking for, and when i found it, it was too expensive. So i decided to design my very own jetboat. As you can se in my other project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1141731) i have already a propeller-powered boat, it is nice and quick, and its funny to follow ducks ;D but it is not very agile, so a jetdrive was the new thing to build. It runs very smooth and its very cheap in the configuration that i used, but i recommend to use another powerplant, despite of it will be a little bit more expensive, with my configuration the motor goes very hot, and at some points it can even partially melt the holder, ending in a motor loose (after giving a lot of gas for 10-20 min)
My powerplant is:
Mabuchi 540 (4.5 Euros at home if you buy 3) http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__79498__Mabuchi_RS_540SH_6527_Brushed_Motor_90W.html
3.175 to 4 mm coupling https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/%5F%5F40743%5F%5FUniversal%5FDrive%5FShaft%5FCoupling%5Ffor%5FBoat%5F23mm%5Fx%5F3%5F17%5F4mm%5F2pc%5F.html
DC ESC http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__9090__Turnigy_20A_BRUSHED_ESC.html
3S 220mAh LiPO http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=10383
9 gram servo http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=662
i didnt calculated but probably you can build your own jetdrive boat under 30 euros
you can see how it runs here https://youtu.be/vU8ZhXroyTs
for the hull i used PVC foam and a lot of hot glue, it can be bougth in sheets and costs 5 euros pro sq meter, i have no plans because i build it by hand ;(
for the shaft i used inoxsteel 4 mm rod, it can e found in some hardware store,
Have fun!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

once you have printed the housing i would recommend you to smooth the inner surface, i have done with sand paper and acetone (i printed in ABS)
in the housing i used m4 nuts drilled with a 4mm -4.2mm drillbit as a bushings
to connect the servo to the jet drive i used hot glue and one of the arms that comes with the servo, i glued on the top screwhole and connected to the servo with 1mm rod.
every screw used is M3, except the ones that hold the turning part, those are wood screws, 3,5 mm exterior diameter.

author: javierru

title: Afinia UP! Print Bed Squaring Pegs

description.text:
I find it fairly frustrating squaring off a print bed on the Afinia. It's particluarly hard when the bed is hot and I'm doing a quick swap-out between fast prints.  
So I designed this pin to fit in the hole of the perf-board which align properly to the print bed itself.  
Just slide two of these pins into the corner holes and you should have near perfect alignment. Then you can use the supplied clips to clip down the board for your print.

title: Sunhokey i3 Extruder Insert For Flex Filaments

description.text:
this tiny part can be installed into the extruder of a Sunhokey Prusa i3 to prevent flex filaments from kinking prior to entering the bowden tube. Now that this problem is solved, I can finally print with flex PLA (haven't tried TPE yet). I'm surprised that it works even with 1.75mm filament diameter and bowden tube setup!
EDIT: I found that you have to disable retraction because flex filaments don't like to be squeezed twice by the drivewheel.
It's held in place with a small drop of superglue. After printing the hole can be cleaned up with a 2mm drill bit for the filament to slide freely.

I needed some different endcaps to finish a project with tubes involved. As there were pretty much different sizes of them I had to write a highly customizable script in OpenSCAD to quickly print them without remodeling for each size or shape of cap. This prints with touching buildplate support for the hole of the cap and for the upper cap overhanging border. Some variations/customizations of the cap can be printed without support as seen in one of the examples. You can also make bottle caps, chair leg caps, walking stick caps, pencil caps, Lego heads, dishes, or even peg-tops!! This is an amazing flexible script and a perfect example of how powerful and easy OpenSCAD is. Don't be affraid if you haven't used it yet. Try it now following the instrucions below, you won't regret. You will learn a valuable tool. I've also uploaded a MakerBot customizer version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1654016 just in case.

Instructions: Just download and install OpenSCAD if you don't have it (its free). Open the .scad file. Edit the parameters at the top of the file in pure and clear plain text and see how the magic is done. Measure your tube and make your calculations. Comments and parameter descriptions included nearby each parameter. Press F6 and wait for the software to render the model. Press the STL icon and export it. Then use your favourite slicer to print your customized endcap. Easy, portable, quick, free, clean and powerful. Endcaps won't be a problem for you anymore !!

Enjoy it as I did !!

description.text:
2020 T-Slot system that you can print!

This is a prototyping kit for building desktop machines.

Update: 7/6/2016

New Parts:

  • Corner Brace
  • 10mm Rod mounts
  • 10mm linear bearing mounts

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 for Extrusion and 0.2 for the rest

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Extrusions should be printed upright, You can scale along Z axis to create longer or shorter extrusions. I print them with a 0.75 nozzle and 0.400 height.

Print one at a time for best plastic adhesion, I typically print about 150mm in about an hour. You might need a raft if your bed axis are very aggressive. Slow the print down after 100mm to prevent toppling.

Mounts and the rest are printed with 0.4 nozzle and 0.200 height. No supports are needed, just pick the most suitable orientation.

Requirements

This system is currently based on M2.5 bolts in the 5-8mm range. If you want to use M3, you should just run a M3 tapping tool through the holes first on a electric drill at low speed.

print_settings.Notes:: To get the weight distribution right, this object needs 100% (or nearly) infill. Be warned that slic3r does not cope terribly well with filled objects so you can get unsightly lumps. The object also contains voids with overhangs, but the print worked out okay for me.

description.text:
This is a celt or rattleback - an object that in spite of its simplicity has a preferred direction of rotation when you spin it on a table. Spin it the wrong way and it slows, starts rocking, and often starts spinning the right way.

A demonstration: https://goo.gl/photos/vXfbPJD4R7eT9vmL6

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

To get the weight distribution right, this object needs 100% (or nearly) infill. Be warned that slic3r does not cope terribly well with filled objects so you can get unsightly lumps. The object also contains voids with overhangs, but the print worked out okay for me.
The layer structure of a 3D print makes the bottom surface a bit too rough fot it to spin well. A few minutes with a piece of sandpaper smoothed mine enough that it now works well.

comments.text: I watched the demo video and was impressed. Then I looked at the 3D view (Thingiview) of the model and to me it looks completely symmetric. I'll admit, I'm slightly stumped as to why this thing has a preferred direction of rotation. The absence of weight from the arrowheads on the opposite sides seems negligible. Brian Lewis used non-negligible lead weights on his rattleback. Would the mysterious action of this model benefit from adding some metal bits at the tails of the arrows?
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: The exterior shape is indeed completely symmetric. The interior is not, or at least, less symmetric: it's divided up into quadrants, two of which are solid and two of which are hollow. This misaligns the axes of the torus with the principal axes of the mass; that is, it means that the axes of the rocking don't line up with where the mass is. On a real one you can (intentionally) see where the mass is by looking through the arrows, which reach into the void. Or you can often hold it up to the light, which shines through the hollow sides but not the solid ones.
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: Thanks for explaining what the interior of the model looks like. Perhaps the Thingiview feature can be improved in the future. I noticed that the 3D viewer on Instructables has many useful features, such as being able to create a plane at any angle and see a cross section of the model. Now I can't wait to try printing this and spinning it / playing with it on a surface that has a little friction!
comments.author: peridot_faceted

comments.text: Just note that it does need a little sanding to rock smoothly - the layers coming out of a printer need to be smoothed down. I don't usually have the patience for postprocessing, but five minutes with some sandpaper will do it.
comments.author: CaptObvious

description.text:
Adds extra storage to the top of your printer! Items* stored inside won't** fall off during transportation***.

*Relatively small items
**might not
***slow and steady movements whilst keeping the machine upright.

This 6-piece set fits on top of the SeeMeCNC Orion Delta 3D Printer. Three anchors lock into place on the corners, right where the towers end.

Note: Photos do not accurately represent models. Due to adjustments during the modeling process and a shortage of time and filament, I ended up keeping an old version of the shelf top IRL that isn't perfectly symmetrical. Please let me know how this works for you.

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

ORION Delta 3D Printer

No

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make sure in MatterControl that the anchor fits on the bed. Bed size 180mm. The outermost corners should be adjusted to line up with the longest diameter of the bed.
Also make sure your bed is level and the Z Height has been calibrated.
Sketchup 2016 and a digital caliper!!!

Print 3x Anchors ~6.5 hours each
And any three walls ~1-2 hours each

comments.text: The side walls, seem to be roughly 3.5mm too short. That is to say that when installed, there is a lot of space between where the side wall slides into the corners and the thick section of the side wall. It all still works fine, just has more of a seem gap there than I would have expected.

description.text: A holder for used needles from insulin pens. Never have anywhere to put used needles. Just clips over handle of my bag of diabetic stuff. Lid clips on and doesn't fall off.

Printer:

xyz duo

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Have printed these in pla and abs on my xyz duo and xyz junior. Have used a raft for the abs prints. Walls are quite thin so infill doesn't really make any difference.

how and why

I became a type one diabetic a couple of years ago, went to hospital with fuzzy eyesight and came out next day with four injections a day, but could be worse. Have found carrying around the test metre, insulin pens and needles ok but trying to carry a sharps bin for used needles a pain so thought I could design something to put them in. Thought having two tubes together would be good as it would allow me to carry new and old needles or just old ones. Only need to carry a days worth.

title: Contactless Metal Detector With Reed Contact
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Description:

This is a metal detector, that is capable of detecting metals that can be magnetized like mild steel. The detection distance to a metal sheet is about 5mm. A pinball is detected till about 4.5mm.
The magnets uses are 5x2mm in size. I also tried larger magnets, but that did not increase the detection distance. Smaller ones did reduce the detection range. The 5mm seems to optimal.
The metal is detected, because its presence disturbs the magnetic field. The field is no longer balanced and that activates the reed switch.

I designed these to detect a pinballs in a pinball machine.
.

Building:

- Heat the copper wires and push them in the sides of the plastic. The wires need to stick out a couple of mm, so you can solder the reed switch wires to it.
- Push the reed switch through the center hole. If closed, use a drill to open the hole.
- Put the 2 magnets in place in such a way that they attract each other.
- Test sensor with a piece of metal. You can hear the reed switch closing and opening. Sometimes you need to rotate the reed contact to find the position where it reacting correctly.  The magnets need to be of equal strength, otherwise the reed contact will not open . 
- Then bend the wires up against the copper wires and solder them.
- Finally push some isolated wires through the side hole, and solder them to the copper wires.

See the photo's how everything is mounted.
.

Materials:

You will need the following parts

- 7mm or 10mm glass reed switch : for example type MKA-10110 from http://www.aliexpress.com/item/2016-Hot-10-pcs-MKA-10110-10-15AT-Magnetic-Sensor-N-O-SPST-Contact-Reed-Switches/32682392705.html 
- 2 pieces of  5cm long  1mm  diameter copper wire
- 2 magnets size 5x2mm or 5x1.8mm from  http://www.banggood.com/100pcs-5mmx2mm-N52-Strong-Round-Magnets-Rare-Earth-NdFeB-Neodymium-Magnets-p-988439.html  . Enough to make 50 sensors!

.

Print:

I used ABS, but PLA , PET or other materials also work. 90% to 100% fill. No support needed.

title: Corner joints for hood enclosure CTC

description.text:
I designed these corner joints to put together the hood of my CTC 3D printer. I didn't draw holes in them because the size depends on the diameter of the bolts you are using. You have to drill them as you drill the perspex sheets.
If you want to do it like me, you need to print 5 90°joints (joint.stl), 8 small 90°joints (jointsmall.stl) and 2 120°joints, (jointangle.stl).
The back of the hood is fixed on the printer, the rest is removable.
The size to cut the perspex sheets are specified in the drawing attached.

title: DVD, Cable Box, DVR, Above TV Adjustable Angle Shelf VESA 200mm Flat Panel HDTV

description.text: I needed to mount a DVD player above my TV in the Nook so the kids will stay in there and eat at the table instead of the living room! Plus I like to work on my RC stuff at the table and I hate commercials on regular TV. So I looked around and found nothing like this available, so I made my own. I wanted it on top of the TV so it would not stick out in the way. If I ever get good internet we can watch Netflix etc. The DVD has Wi-Fi. This is a 39" TV, but it should work on others if they have 200mm bolt spacing.

I printed this in ABS, but PLA should be fine as well and possibly more rigid. I put Velcro on the bottom of the shelf (the fuzzy side), and it rests on top of the TV. I Velcroed the DVD player to the shelf so it cannot be knocked off. The DVD feet do grab good, but I think it is safer to Velcro it down.
I used a 6mm socket head bolt, washer, star washer, and nut to fasten the shelf to the legs. I also needed a slightly longer 6mm bolt for the mounting to the TV (the ones I had for my mount were a bit too short with the added bracket.
The star washer was used in between the shelf and legs to help lock it where you snug down the bolt. I did leave a tiny gap in the design to account for this. About .5mm on each side. There is enough flex in the ABS, that you could leave it out if you wanted, especially if resting it on the TV like I did.
Layer height = .3
Perimeters = 2
Top solid layers = 3
Bottom solid layers = 3

description.text:
Voronoi Pearl Light Lamp No. 1 for LED-Spots or LED tealight candle

Small lamp > big impact! This Voronoi Pearl Light Lamp is a beautiful decoration and lamp. Through the voronoi-parts, the light casts a beautiful light and shadow effect. The Voronoi Pearl Lamp looks so at day and night very nice and is therefore ideally suited as a decoration.

Original size: Ca. 10.4 x 10.4 x 6.8 cm

The Lamp is composed of two parts (shells) which are set on each other. Simply inserting an LED tea light candle or a other LED-light in the inside of the bottom part.

If you have no 3D-printer, you can buy a printed copy here:
https://www.shapeways.com/product/CVHRAND83/

Or a little lamp version:
https://www.shapeways.com/product/WRFYSZVL9/

More printed lamps and candleholder etc. in different sizes and shapes can be found here:
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/designgravity

Notes:

Printed with black PLA.

Without support.

Lighting

I use as lighting for example the cheapest LED spot of IKEA ("LEDBERG" LED spot) and the light is impressive (photos).

Important: Please use only LED lights. Do not use real tea lights!

author: dprayson

description.text:
This is a 2 extruder mod for Prusa Mendel 3D printer. The mod is for Makergear hotends and Greg Frost's extruder design v3. The firmware is based on Marlin. The electronics are RAMPS v1.4.
Note: A more advanced version of this is mod is RepRap X2V3.

The mod is likely to work for multiple configurations, but in my case the extruders are based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8252 and the X-carriage is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9869. The hotends are from Makergear. The electronics are RAMPS 1.4. Mechanics: The extruders are mounted on the sides of the printer and the filament is driven through the PTFE tubes (A. Bowden's mount). I'm using 3mm (my extruders easily break the 1.75mm filament), but I experimented with 1.75mm too (the adapter Sketchup file has models for 2x1.75mm and 1x3mm+1x1.75mm adapter configurations). The instructions are pretty straightforward.
  • print 2 extruder mounts;
  • print the adapter and the 2 hotends mount (based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7107 I believe - not sure was a while ago).
  • print the second extruder (note: you have to print mirrored version of the extruder body if want the printer to look symmetrical).
    • Putting in the hotends requires quite a bit of force, but they have to be snag to avoid wobbling. There are pictures (those with pliers) showing the steps of putting the hotends in. Put the first one in (that is easy), then position the second one like it is shown on the picture and use the screwdriver to drive it in (use a bigger screwdriver than the one shown). It requires quite a bit of force. After the corner of the second extruder mount goes into the groove of the first one use the screwdriver tip to drive it further into its space. Note, that you are unlikely to be able to take it out without cutting the mount, so might be a good idea to print a spare one just in case. In order to make the 3mm filament drives you'll need 2 PTFE tubes about 2 feet each (mcmaster.com part #52365K611 http://www.mcmaster.com/#52365k611). I initially ordered 2 feet ones, but had to cut off 95-100mm. Use a file to point the ends of the tubes and screw on M6 nuts to the ends (might be a bit hard to start, but as the threads catch they'll move on). After the nuts are on clean up the excess of the PTFE sticking out from the other sides of the nuts. Use the appropriately sized drill bits to widen the inner hole where nuts compressed the PTFE tube and make sure no PTFE pieces get inside. Put the filament drive tube ends into the mounts, then remove the little plastic caps holding the vertical smooth rods in place and screw on the extruder mounts.
    Note: you'll need at least 435mm treaded rods on top of the printer (those that hold the Z-motor mounts) to screw on the side extruder mounts. Tthey should be long enough (440mm) if you cut the rods according to the RepRap wiki instructions. Put on the hotend mount onto the X-carriage and screw it on at the corners. Now it is a good time to level the hotends. 2 out of 3 times I was able to level them just by holding the hotend's PEEK mount with pliers and screwing in the nozzle w/ heater barrel a bit more on the hotend that was sticking out. One time I had to unscrew the nozzle w/ the barrel and file the barrel top a bit. It is important to level the hotends as precisely as possible. Put the free ends of the filament drive tubes with nuts on them into the adapter holes. Drive pieces of the filament through the tubes (starting from the extruder mount sides) till 10-15mm of it sticks out of the adapter tube end. Guide the sticking out filament into the hotens and then screw on the adapter on top of the hotend mount. Now it is a good time to check again that the hotends are leveled. If everything looks OK pull out the filament. You can now screw on the extruders to the side mounts and move on to connecting the wires. Electronics: You'll need the motor, the stepper driver and the wiring for the second extruder. The second hotend heater is connected to D9 (instead of the fan) and the termistor is connected to TERM2 pin. If you'd like to use the hotend fan, then you might need to make an external fan control board (will need at least a mosfet). I use a breadboard (see picture) attached to the printer side and just wired 12v then built the same mosfet switch like they use in RAMPS (see RAMPS schematics, Heaters & Fans part). I've used IRF510 mosfet that happened to be nearby when needed. The control wire comes from "servos" connector pin D4. Software: The modifications to support multiple extruders were made to the Marlin firmware. It was giving me the best prints and there were some hooks to get started with. In order to get the code (assuming you have git) do this:
    git clone git://github.com/dob71/Marlin.git
    cd Marlin
    git checkout Marlin_v1
    Then go ahead and edit the Configuration.h (the instructions are in the file) and build the firmware. Here are the major commands (available at this moment) related to the multiple extruders setup:

  • T [F] [S] - select extruder ("n" is the number of the extruder to select, "speed" is the feed rate at which to make the move for positioning the selected extruder, "S" controls either the E axis coordinate should be treated independenly or considered to be continuous to that of the extruder "m").
    After the extruder is selected the generic commands that do not have extruder specified in the arguments will apply to the selected extruder only;

  • M104 [T]... - can accept extruder number to set the temperature for;

  • M105 [T]... - can accept extruder number to show the temperature for;

  • M109 [T]... - can specify which extruder to wait for.
    • Note: If you are using an old Printrun version, you might need to change Ã¢â¬Åpronsole.pyÃ¢â¬Â to enable the 'T' command. Find and replace the following line:
  • if(l[0]=='M' or l[0]=="G"):
  • if(l[0]=='M' or l[0]=='G' or l[0]=='T'):
    • You can use the X2SW software package ( http://github.com/dob71/x2swn/wiki ) that installs Printrun, Skeinforge, Slic3r and sets them up to work together. Use the RepRap/X2/x2_0200 experimental profile unless there is one avialable specifically for your printer. Notes: The retract speed is very important for this kind of filament drive. I have to retract 5mm and start the retract at the highest speed possible to avoid blobs (there is a parameter in Configuration.h allowing to configure initial speed for retract moves). So far I was mostly using the dual extruders setup to switch easily between 0.5 and 0.35mm hotends or between ABS and PLA. Switching between PLA and ABS for printing support vs the object itself didn't give me results much better that printing everything in the same material. Since extruder change repositions the extruder you might hit endstop if doing it too close to the perimeter of the printing area. If you do not need to switch extruders in the middle of the print can just put zeroes for the extruder offset in the Configuration.h. Here is the first attempt to print something useful in multiple colors:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17670

title: Prusa i3 MKII buildplate Camera mount

description.text:
EDIT: 2016-12-27

NEW VERSION HERE: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/original-prusa-i3-mk2-camera-mount-26525

EDIT: 2016-10-08

Added a more "bulky" vertical arm with a flat top as well as a top mount for my Logitech C160. I'll glue the top to onto the arm.

new test timelapse: https://youtu.be/KiaT0QOFWug

EDIT: 2016-07-07

With higher temperatures on the heated bed, the PLA version I first printed melted down, so I recommend using PETG, ABS or similar.

EDIT: 2016-07-01

V2: Redesigned it a lot! This is not as "wiggly" sideways
Added a test timelapse: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwoPSTmSV_c&feature=youtu.be

Tired of my time laps being all chaotic and I wanted to mount my camera onto the build plate for better time lapses.

Since the extruder uses the whole plate I needed to use the frame that the buildplate sits upon to attach my camera "arm". I'm still waiting for my long Raspberry Pi Camera cable (1 meter), so I cant add a time lapse example now but will do that as soon as I receive it. I've uploaded the view from the long arm at least. The long arm can be dissembled to a short arm as well if you print smaller models or just want to keep track of your print. Use M2 bolts to secure the arm to the metal frame as well as the two arms together to get that extra length. Also the camera case itself can be attached using M2 bolts and nut.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

I printed the arm with low infill and the mount + case parts with 100% infill to get some extra strength for mounting. Supports for the "grip's" that holds on to the frame.

The recently added logitech knob for the logitech webcam is printed in 0.1mm layerheight, and then glued onto the "prusa_camera_arm_mount_thicker_with_flat_top.stl"

Assembly

Use either the short arm, or the short + long arm, depending on what POV you like/need. The mounts for the camera case is glued on place. It's a bit fragile so take it careful when you assembling the camera case to the arm with the mount.

Longer arm means more vibrations though.

Ordered a long camera cable from here:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/For-Raspberry-Pi-Camera-1m-FRC-Flexible-Round-Cable-1xFFC-Kit-pi-cables-/111366510311?hash=item19edf616e7:g:paMAAOxy9X5TZMj-

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: I have published instruction on Instructables: http://www.instructables.com/id/Tertiarm-3d-Printed-Robot-Arm/ and add new parts!

This is a 3D printed robot arm based on Ikea Tertial lamp.
I use lamp because it has very good kinematic with using springs to unload servos.
I cut all beam, but you can use any length.
It has 5 DOF and use 5 standart size servo.
You can find list of all components and printing part in BOM.
I haven't done any instruction yet, but I will be happy to answer all your question.
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoLEyxQzFfY
My project on Hackaday.io: https://hackaday.io/project/19235-tertiarm-3d-printed-robot-arm
Lifting power test video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o4JGR529i1o

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

40-100%

comments.text: I went through your Instructable briefly. It states to cut all beams to a specific length. Do you mean to say that I need to cut / saw the lamp after disassembling?
comments.author: ptrgan

comments.text: Sorry for the long answer. Yes, you need to cut all beams, but the specific length depends on your servo torque and power. You even can use the default length, but the best one is 260mm.
comments.author: ptrgan

comments.text: cool idea. They don't sell that IKEA lamp in California. Do you just use the aluminum square tube and springs from it?
comments.author: uwe999

comments.text: Thank you. You can use aluminium square tube and similar spring from hardware store. You just need to check the right size of tube using Tip.STL from thing files. Square is about 10x10mm(outside) and about 9x9mm(inside).
comments.author: uwe999

thanks! Found out that they do sell the LED version of that lamp in California

description.text:
So after the V-Engine Model i decided to do a Boxer Engine this shows pretty well the difference between V and Boxer Engines.

So now you can Print the famous engine type used in BMW-Motorcycles, Porsches or Subarus.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

l3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Print twice: Conrod 1 and 2, Cylinder, Piston, Pistonbolt
Rest has only to be printed once.

Support is needed at the Cylinders and the Crankshaft.

Push the Crankshaft 1 and 2 through the Housing and put the Crank on it as well. You won´t need glue here as the fitting is really tight.
Sand down the innerpart of the Cylinders a bit.
Glue the Cylinders to the Housing make sure the holes allign well.
Stick the Pistonbolt through Piston and Conrod 1.
Push the Pistons into the Cylinders and glue the Cornrod 2 on the other side pay attention that you don´t glue it on the Crankshaft.
I designed it using Catia V5

Creating the piece

Below is a list of material also used in this piece, all of which can be found at your local art/craft store
1- 18"x24" cotton canvas.

  1. Super Glue
  2. Absorbant Ground
  3. Paint
    After all the objects had been printed They were arranged to what I thought was a pleasing formation before attaching to a canvas.Using the super glue attach your objects to the canvas. and let dry. I then applied several layers of an absorbant ground. The absorbant ground makes it easier for paint to adhere to both canvas and the object.

Design Process

Using Tinkercad I created flat base object(meaning that on side was flat) so that later it could be a attached to a canvas. in this example I used the half round object and made changes to size and height to create an appealing visual effect.

title: GnomIoT - The Solar Powered Garden Sensor

description.text:
Monitor your garden with this IoT powered Garden Gnome!

Sensors: Outdoor Temperature, Humidy, Soil Maisture, Swimming Pool Temperature and Water Level

Power: LiPo Battery and Solar Panel

Radio: Wifi and Cloud enabled with online/mobile dashboard https://freeboard.io/board/7XJ6_T

Requires

  • 1 Particle Photon WiFi controller
  • 1 LiPo Rider Solar Battery Charger
  • 1 Solar Panel
  • 1 Waterproof Temperature Sensor, DHT11 Sensor and Soil Moisture
  • 1 Breadoard + Various Resistances

(Average cost: ~60$)

How To
Assemble the circuit following the pictures below, then add some duct tape to keep all the parts on the breadboard and insert it in the gnome.
The cables for the sensors can be passed through the rear hole with the small cover over it to avoid that the rain will go inside.

All the juncture of the gnome model are embossed to avoid water/humidity.

Best printed in Laybrick or Wood filaments. Can be painted in acrylic to better impermeability.

The Code

  • Load the code in the attachments of this thing to your Particle Build IDE (PARTICLE-LOOP, ONEWIRE and HTTPCLIENT libraries required, found in the libraries section)
  • Change the Dweet name in the first part of the script to a name of your choice
  • Open the Freeboard dashboard and clone it (with the Clone button at the bottom of the dashboard) and change the Datasource on the top right panel with your dweet name.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Best printed with temperature resistant materials like ABS, Laybrick or Wood

Easy Version

Requires:

1 Particle Photon Board
1 LiPo Rider Solar Battery Charger
1 Temperature Sensor
5 10k Ohm Resistances
1 Breadboard

Advanced Version

Requires also:

1 DHT11 Temp/Humidty Sensor
1 Soil Humidity Sensor
1 Extra 10k Resistance

Advanced Version

Greetings

Based on the Makerbot Gnome model

description.text:

Korpus needs some Support Material but may work without on good Printers have fun

author: larrythecat123

description.text:
recommended to download and modify the design according to your pi's dimensions casue its a tight fit for mine

it has some ventilation hole
(TIP: if you want more ventilation make some holes in the top and it can fit a heat sink system of 24mm in height )

I made some (screw like) lock clips to open and close at your need so no screw, nut 'n bolt,or glue

please feel free to comment your thoughts : )

Things I used

1 -> Raspberry pi 3
2 -> Tailors Tape ( I will buy a vernier caliper soon)
3 -> Pen 'n Paper
4 -> some geometry mathematics
